I didn't even want to go down that road. And so I, I feel like point for me to actually kind of
return and say like, no, I'm going to, I'm going to find, I'm going to go deeper into learning about
myself kind of from a scriptural lens, almost like a biblical counseling perspective, I guess.
And, yeah, I think ever since then, ever since then, it's still not easy, right? And there's still
sin in my life. And I am, I'm just a person who needs grace every single day. And, but I,
I know what I believe, right? And I'm, I'm happy to walk through that and try to try to show that
for other people, because I'm not perfect. And I'm not, I don't have everything figured out. And
I'm, I'm not even your, like, I don't even do all the things that people would say a good Christian
is supposed to do all the time, but I try to. And I, and I do know what I believe in terms of
who Jesus Christ is and what the resurrection meant for me. And I think that that's anyways,
we're getting on, I'm a little off track, I'm rambling now, but that's kind of where my
I mean, you're talking about the gospel. That's not off track. Yeah, right. Right.
But I think that's, I mean, yeah, that's, that's awesome. Do you mind if I interrupt real quick?
Cause cause what you were talking about kind of those two, those two big things,
at least that you were mentioning kind of the, the person who was kind of a staple or a pillar in
your life. And maybe, maybe you wouldn't classify them as a pillar, but just the infidelity aspect
of like, gosh, okay. I think that's really relatable. And then also the counselor, you know,
you're saying, what do I believe? What, what I feel like Chris says a lot as he speaks,
is we need to deconstruct our faith in humanity. And I feel like that ourselves. Yeah. Yeah. And so
I feel like that's a huge part of it is like, until you are met with those crises, sometimes
you don't realize how much, how much stock you do put into yourself or you put into other people
who are not, who are not, you know, the savior of who are not your savior. And because, because of
that, it's like people are going to fail you. And so, so yeah, I think that that's really
relatable. And then I really liked what you were saying of my body's not a reliable source of truth.
I think that's such a counter cultural thing today too, of like, of the whole, the, you know,
hyper individualism, my truth, you know, part of our culture that I feel like that that's really
cool that you were saying that, but I was also like, as my, my questions kind of come from,
okay, as you're going through this crisis, were you, were you still involved with the body of Christ?
Did you go through any, any point of isolation? Because I feel like that a lot of those things
kind of go hand in hand of like, yeah, you know, and so I don't know, I don't know what that looks
like for you. And I, and I know that like some parts of Colorado are, are a little bit more
spiritually dry than let's say where we are right now in the, you know, the, the middle of the Bible
belt, you know, or the buckle of the Bible belt, the same people say. So I don't know, but what is,
what does that look like for you as you've been going through this?
Even in like closeness to community. Is that kind of what you're, what you're referencing?
Yes, exactly. Exactly. Because I feel like some people who have talked about deconstruction have
really distanced themselves from any sort of challenging thinking or any sort of what they
believed is true. And then kind of deviated to where it's like, okay, I'm going to find people who
have kind of affirming voices. And then it's like, man, I'm, I'm way, I'm in a way different place
surrounded by way different people than before. Right, right. Yeah, for me, I went through
probably a short period of that when I went to Boise. Like when all this stuff was happening,
I was kind of put in my first, I was, I was literally in my first situation outside of my
undergraduate degree where I wasn't working for a Christian ministry. Right. So it was just kind of
this for a while. And honestly, like I went to Boise kind of being burned out on ministry stuff,
like some of what I was talking about earlier, in terms of just the politics that had been going on
I went up there partly to kind of get a break. And so, so when I first moved there, yeah, I didn't
get super plugged into a church right away. And then I tried to I tried to get plugged into a
small church that was kind of a, I think it was an axe 29 startup. And I got told, hey, we don't
want you on the worship team until you go through our membership class. And I was like, well, okay,
so when's the membership class happening? And they're like, well, it happens once a month.
I was like, okay, when when's the next one? I was like, well, it was last week. And then I was like,
when's the next one? And then they're like, well, we're not sure yet. We'll have to let you know.
And so I was like, okay. And then like two or three weeks later, they're like, oh, membership
class this afternoon, like, like this afternoon, like I'm supposed to cut three hours out of the
Sunday that I had already planned to go do some other things and have obligations for.
And you never told me. And then on top of that, I found out at whenever I went finally got through
the membership class and these interviews and everything else, there's a buddy sitting next to
me who was on the worship team. I was like, Hey, what are you doing here today at the congregational
meeting? He's like, Oh, I'm being confirmed as a member today, just like you are. I was like,
Wait a second. So you've been on the worship team for the last four months and you weren't a member.
How is that possible? Because that's not what they told me.
Yeah, inconsistency and disorganization. And it was just, it was a frustrating experience.
Yeah. So that was all happening on top. And then, but then like the second half of my
time in Boise, I got plugged into an amazing Christian church. And there was a worship pastor
there who really took me under zooming. And I asked him to mentor me and he did. And so there
was just like all this stuff happening. And then I don't know, I'm rambling a little, but like,
but the Lord did provide somebody to talk through some of these things with me. It just took a little
while. But I'll say like, kind of from a more meta perspective is just that, you know, I think I
heard the guy you had on last week, just talking about how his parents had helped be intentional
about what the church was. And I don't think my parents did this on purpose, but I think the
church has always been like a pretty safe place for me. And so for me, it's always been like,
even if people are not treating me well in some ways, like I've seen a good church, you know,
like I grew up in a pretty good church. And it was just a place of safety for me. And I knew if
I could find the right group of people, there would be people who apply their intellect to
the Christian faith, and you could have good deep conversations. And so it just took a while to find
that I think during that season of life. But it sounds like that helped because I know, you know,
for people who haven't had that experience, sometimes it's hard to disconnect the way that
believers or like nominal believers have acted, you know, like even like that counselor, even if
he was a Christian, like, it sounds like you were able to like separate when Christians weren't
acting like Christ or like following Scripture. Yeah. Not like lumping it with the whole church
or, you know, whatever it is. But, but I that's crazy, though, because last week we were talking
about or I don't know when this is gonna post drop, but we were talking about how a lot of times it's
easy as Christians just to take secular ideas and phrases and slap a Christian label on them. And
it sounds like that's what that counselor was doing of like, the whole like Colson was saying,
the whole radical autonomy concept of like, you know, you know, what is fulfilling and what's
gonna make you happy. And it's like, wait, that's like, that's straight from the world,
not from Scripture, like you're saying, but yeah, what are so where I have a question, just what
was it like going through a season of like wrestling and struggle after having been someone
who has like realistically walked through a lot of that with a lot of other people. So you've taught
like worldview apology, I'm sure. At some point, you've walked through hard questions with other
people, or struggles or addictions. So what was it? I'm just curious, like, what was that like,
having to wrestle with that in yourself after having been someone who's like an authority in
other people's lives in that way? Does that make sense? Yeah, I think that like, at some point,
even as a Christian leader, I had to come to grips with the term that I'm still a sinner,
right? And that I can still make mistakes. Practically and personally, and I can make
mistakes in intellect, I can make mistakes in spiritual coaching, you know, I can make
mistakes in the things that I say. And so I think going through that, you know, like there is a,
as a Christian leader, who's dealing with some of those things, there can be a stark loneliness to
it, right? Because if you feel like if you, if you talk to your superior about it, you might get
fired, right? Or if you talk to a peer about it, they might report you or, you know, it just
depends on what you're going through. But there's in, and I get it, like, I think in some ways there
are there. I don't know, I get it, like, like students, especially at a high school summer camp
where I would work and teach sometimes, like, parents are entrusting you with their kids, and
that has to be like a safe place as much as possible. And so you have to be really cautious
about that. But at the same time, if there's, if you don't have an avenue for that outlet, then it's,
it can be really lonely and difficult. But thankfully, like, I've had some good friends,
just in my years of working through ministry, I just have a few friends who, if I'm like,
if I'm struggling with something, I can go and talk to them. And it's not like a cliche
accountability partner thing. Like, I was trying to be part of an accountability group in college,
it was the worst experience ever. It was mostly just really awkward, no one was being very honest
about anything. But then it's like, hey, you have friends that you end up spending time with,
and, you know, at one point, you just, you get to a place of such desperation where you're willing
to say like, hey, I just really need to like talk to somebody about this. I'm really having a hard
time. And, and you don't even have to tell all the details, but just the ability to like,
have someone pray for you, and the ability to have someone hear you is super, super helpful.
So I had probably two friends in the last six years, maybe three friends, that I can literally
do that with anything. And they're not going to judge me. They're just going to listen. And they'll,
they will be trustworthy with the vulnerability. So yeah, I think, I think that's awesome. And I
think that's really encouraging, because that's something that we keep coming back to, even as
we've like, worked through the hard things that's happened in like the greater church body. And like,
you know, you see Christian leader after Christian leader just have colossal falls, you know, over
and over again. And we've like talked through like the things that you're saying of like,
we have to be able to admit that we're sinful, we're broken, doesn't matter what position or,
or whatever that you find yourself in, like, we have to be able to ask hard questions and show
that vulnerability. Because the minute we start pretending like we have it all together, and the
minute we start pretending like we don't have doubts, or, or even worse, when we start isolating
ourselves and not being vulnerable with anyone, because we're in a place of leadership, or because
there's like pride involved, or whatever it is, like, that's often what prompts like years and years
of something happening where, you know, that ends up being these scandals that we see. But all that
just that's really encouraging, because I think it's hard to do that. Well, I think it's what you
find yourself in a place of all these people know me as this, or I'm in a place of leadership, or
people look up to me, or like, whatever the situation is. I think it's hard to get to a place
where you're, you're willing to admit like, hey, I'm broken, I'm sinful, I, none of us are beyond
anything. And that's like a really, that's like a really powerful place to be, but it's hard to get
to that place. Yeah, vulnerability. And, and then sometimes it's easy if it goes on so long,
sometimes it's easy just to turn and be like, I'm done with all of this because the vulnerabilities.
Yep. Right. And then the continuing struggle, I think is too hard. Yeah. Yeah. Okay, so I had a
couple things I wanted to talk about. I don't know if we have for him. But so in talking to some
people who have had friends go through deconstruction, or who've gone through some deconstruction
themselves, I think we're hitting on a lot of good things here. I did, I think first people want to
know that they're hurt. Right. Right. Like people want to know that they their concern will be taken
seriously. And I think blowing off. Yeah. And so I wanted to like, one point I really wanted to make
is to challenge any leaders who are listening to this, or anyone who's listening who's had a bad
leader, maybe, but I want to speak to church leaders and just say, like, look, if you outlaw
a conversation topic, you plant seeds of dissension immediately. I mean, immediately. And I think
that's just because look, if you're if you're dealing with high school students or individuals,
or whatever the situation is, and you say, No, we will not talk about this, whether that's dating,
or sex, or alcohol, or anything that like high school students are going to start to be exposed
to, whenever they're getting into their their later years, if you just outlaw it, what you're
doing is you're closing down the opportunity to give them the wisdom that you have. Right.
And oftentimes that that outline is because it is an unwillingness to show the vulnerability of
yourself, right? Like, I've had some mentors who, excuse me, they don't want to talk about these
things. I've had some mentors who don't want to talk about these things, because they've struggled
with them in the past, right? And so the trying to navigate something wisely is a really daunting
task for them, because it consumed them when they were younger. But the fact is, if a student isn't
educated from their mentor, or whoever that leadership position is, they will be educated
from somewhere else. Right. And that's totally, that's what we're talking about with with some
of the changing community groups from like Christians to non Christians or whatever,
is that somebody tried to ask a question, they didn't get it, they got shut down. So they're
going to go somewhere where they can ask that question. And that that may be Instagram, it may
be YouTube, it may be, right, it may be a book or a movie, or it may be a friend's house,
but they will be educated on it somehow. And so when you shut down the opportunity to talk about
that, you shut down that opportunity to teach wisdom. And so I don't know, I just want to
challenge people that if you've had somebody shut you down before, number one, it's probably
because that leader was not willing to be vulnerable in that way. Or number two, it's just,
yeah, they just missed out on an opportunity. And that's not good leadership, frankly.
Yeah, yeah. And it like presents the idea of like, if you're a certain level of Christian,
all these things are off the table, which is like not the gospel at all.
Right. Right. It's crazy. I mean, if you think about like, if you just think a little bit
about the Bible, I mean, David was a murderer, right? And he doubted all the time. Gideon was a
doubter constantly. And frankly, he was a pretty big coward, who had to constantly just be reaffirmed
in what God had clearly told him to do. Abraham lied about his wife being his sister multiple times.
Right. And it's just like, who are these people? And so like, I just think the point is like,
look, if you're, if you have doubts, if you got questions, it's like, welcome to the table, right?
Not only do all these modern people have doubts and questions, but all the people in the Bible
had doubts and questions. Yeah, yeah. It's just like not a foreign concept. And it's amazing.
Yesterday, yesterday, I went to church up in Fort Collins with a friend, and the Bible
passage they opened with was Matthew 28. And you're just like, oh, Matthew 28, 18. It's the Great
Commission, right? Everybody knows that one. But if you look just before that, Matthew 28, 17,
but I'm going to back up on that one. So starting in Matthew 28, 16. So now the 11 disciples went
to Galilee to the mountain which Jesus had directed them. And when they saw them, and when
they saw him, they worshiped him, but some doubted. And Jesus came to them and said, all authority in
heaven and earth were given to me, go therefore make disciples of all nations. Right. And it's
just like right before this seminal foundational verse, it's like this is a resurrected Jesus
standing with these apostles. And the byline is they worship him, but some doubted. And it's like,
wait, what, what, what? Like this guy's standing in front of you. You saw this guy crucified,
now he's standing in front of you. And the thing that the Bible wants you to remember is like, hey,
they worshiped him, but some still did like, geez. Yeah, so I just think like, yeah, if you're,
if somebody's doubting, like, welcome to the table, there's that's not a taboo thing. It's not an
unfamiliar thing in Scripture. David in the Psalms clearly doubts he, he doubts God working
in his life. He doubts God's plan for his life. He doubts whether God has his goodness in mind,
like all these things. It's not a foreign concept. So yeah, the last thing I wanted to say is,
there's a great book called Gentle and lowly. I know it's really popular right now. But it's a
really great verse or a great book, I think kind of on this topic. And a really big point that it's
made that I think really struck home for me was like, God's glory is made larger in my weaknesses.
Right. God's like, if God exists, you know, there's a whole theological construct to this,
but like, if God exists for his own glory, then my weakness actually heightens that glory.
My needing mercy and needing grace extends the goodness of who he is. And it's not like he's a
teacher who's just looking down to punish me saying, look, you're taking away from the good
that I'm doing on earth, which I might be, but the good that he's doing on earth is also him working
within me. And so that's, that's just a really, that's been a really powerful thing for me to
remember during some of these things is because you don't have to have it all together to be
Christian. You don't have to have all the answers to be Christian. You just have to know that you
need a savior, honestly. And that's, I think a lot of us, I mean, there's some resources I could give
if you don't know that. But well, and that's, that's what that was my next question for you, August was
you, you did such a good job of explaining that yet doubting is not wrong. And there is a place
for you with all believers, if you're doubting, because we're all in the same part, if there's
somebody listening though, who is dealing with doubt for the first time in an honest way, or they
are kind of helping shepherd somebody through that kind of initial, like, fearful moments of like,
wait, okay, wait, what do I believe? And is this, is this something I can stand on? What would be
your encouragement for that person who's going through it for the first time? Like, if you're
going to have a conversation, what would it be? Yeah. Well, that kind of brings me to my second
point, right, which is the first point being people want to be heard, right. And if you're
willing to listen to them, and actually, you know, take their concerns seriously, and, you know,
then I think people are willing to open up and be vulnerable, and they'll often mirror vulnerability
that you show in that process. So first, they want to be heard. And then second,
I think if people are really working through something, honestly, my question is, well,
okay, you're wrestling with some of these things. How do we know what truth is? Right. And just
start there, right? How do we know what truth is? Because if you don't, if you if you're at a point
where you're saying, I'm not sure I can trust the Bible, then there are books written on that,
like why the Bible is trustworthy, the history that goes into it, how it was created,
that are these awesome wells of knowledge regarding just apologetics, right, the defense of
the Christian faith, that you can go and explore. And I would really challenge people to do that.
Like, if you feel like you're in your hangups are intellectual, then don't then don't don't hide on
intellectualism. But you got to do the work, right? And you got to be willing to actually go find the
answer. So a couple couple resources, I wanted to say a book that really meant a lot to me,
was Lee Strobel's The Case for Christ. It was a very clear pouring out of just facts of like,
this is what happened around the resurrection. This is what a crucifixion was. This is why it
was impossible for Christ to have just fainted and then woken up three days later. Or this is why it
was impossible for him for the disciples to have stolen the body. I mean, even within the Bible,
there's no logic to that idea. And so, so being willing to kind of look for that. So Lee Strobel's
The Case for Christ. Arab Metaxas, this is a little bit of a more modern book called Miracles.
And it just talks about the kind of the case for a creator based on the statistics of our existence,
right? The fact that the earth is on the axis that it is and the correct distance from the sun is like
a crazy statistical analysis that that would even be possible ever by chance. And the fact that there
are like more than 100, more than that probably, 100 criteria for life to even exist. Just the fact
of saying that it's random chance is basically impossible. So that's a really great one. And then
a good author I've actually haven't read, but I know his great reputation is Sean McDowell.
He has a book called Apologetics for a New Generation. So look, so I would say number
one, right, if somebody is in that area, you have to ask the question of how are you going to establish
truth, right? How are you going to establish how do you know what you know,
your epistemology, right? That's the big word for it. Yeah, how are you going to establish how do
you know what you know? Because if you're just going to look into yourself, then how do you,
how do you rectify the fact that sometimes you change your mind? Yeah, yeah. And if you're going
to look outside and say, well, it's majority rules, well, has the majority ever been wrong? I mean,
there's some ways to think through these things where you just say, how do you know what you know?
And if you're willing to give the Bible a shot, then I think there's some great resources to
undergird the strength of Scripture as being trustworthy from a historical, from the artifacts
that have been found, and from a logical point of view. So that's awesome. That's kind of where I
would start. What do you think about that? Is that too intellectual for you, Colson?
Sorry. Not at all, man. I think that is really great.
Well, that's actually like one of the things that we've talked about a lot is like,
removing a lot of the fear that comes from crisis of faith or life of like, hey, like you're saying,
just because you're having this question for the first time, most likely, you're not the first
person to ever have this question. And you're not the first person to think through it. And
there are people who have gone before you. But like you're saying, you have to do the work
to not only deconstruct, but also reconstruct what you do, believe in why. And I think that's
perfect. That's exactly what we've talked about. Colson, is there anything that you were at,
where you're going to add? I had an unrelated question. So,
if you have any related questions, can you tell me about this? Can you,
can you tell me about this majestic mountain goat that is in a frame behind you?
Because I've been looking at it like, Oh, did he draw that? Like,
yeah. So it's actually one of my best friend's wife, uh, through that. So she did that one.
There's an Eagle face over here, but she did as well. So I think she, there's a bighorn sheep
that's in my house too, that she did. So anyways, yeah, she's, she outfitted me with all these.
So I love it. And the other thing was what's the name of your band?
It's called Westrock W E S T R O C K Westrock. It's all one word. Yeah. We have one album out.
We're working on our second one right now. It should be out in July. And, um, yeah,
it's been really good. We've, I've been really thankful to, to be able to play music this year.
Are you touring? That's awesome. Colson is our, oh, sorry. Go ahead. No, no, I was, uh,
yeah, not, not, so we just tour regionally. So we kind of tour within Colorado. Um,
I'm really hoping in like, uh, October to maybe get a rundown to Texas when it kind of cools off
a little bit and kind of do some fall parties down there. Um, but we'll, we haven't toured much
outside of Colorado and Wyoming yet right now, but, but yeah, we've had, we've got 70 shows on
the books for this year and yeah. And we've, um, opened for four or five Nashville acts. So we're,
we're working hard to kind of get going with it. Yeah. That is awesome. That's awesome. That's
great. That's so fun. Well, I know we could, I feel like we could just talk forever on all
a lot of these topics, but I, I really appreciate, um, I mean your vulnerability and you just your
wisdom and, um, your, you know, years of, I've just always appreciated that about you. You like,
you think, well, you're honest, you're vulnerable. Um, and you push others to do the same. And that's
why I was really wanting to have you on. And I'm really thankful for what you shared. And I hope
it's, I know that it will be encouraging to others as well, but awesome. Yeah. Thanks,
Bryn. I'm really excited and I'm thankful to have been on the show too. I put on my Instagram
last week, whenever you asked me to be on it, I was just like, Hey, you know, does anyone have
stories of deconstruction they'd be willing to share. And I wasn't able to talk to many of those
people before this interview, but, um, I am supposed to be talking to them in the next few days. And
I'm just really excited. They reached out though. Yeah. Yeah. I'm really thankful that this created
an opportunity to at least have a conversation. Cause it's people who are kind of across the
country that I've just kept up with on social media or whatever. So yeah, it's, it's already
been fruitful just to, just to start a conversation. So that's awesome. Well, that's our hope that it
sparks conversation and continues that. So thanks. Thanks. We love having you on.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith. If you enjoyed what you
heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info
at southspring.org. Reconstructed faith is a resource of South spring Baptist church.
Remember don't give up trust. God search for answers.
